text: And she say to me, Both drink thou, and I will also draw for thy camels: let the same be the woman whom the LORD hath appointed out for my master's son.
text_kjv: And she say to me, Both drink thou, and I will also draw for thy camels: let the same be the woman whom the LORD hath appointed out for my master's son.
text_niv: and if she says to me, “Drink, and I’ll draw water for your camels too,” let her be the one the Lord has chosen for my master’s son.’
text_esv: and who will say to me, “Drink, and I will draw for your camels also,” let her be the woman whom the LORD has appointed for my master's son.’
text_nlt: If she says, “Yes, have a drink, and I will draw water for your camels, too,” let her be the one you have selected to be the wife of my master’s son.’
text_msg: and she says, Not only will I give you a drink, I'll also water your camels—let that woman be the wife God has picked out for my master's son.'
text_nasb: and she will say to me, 'You drink, and I will draw for your camels also'; let her be the woman whom the LORD has appointed for my master's son.'
context: Genesis 24 recounts Abraham's deliberate efforts to find a wife for his son Isaac from among his own people, avoiding the Canaanite women. He dispatches his trusted servant, likely Eliezer of Damascus, on this crucial mission. Verse 44 highlights a key aspect of Eliezer's divinely inspired test. Water was incredibly precious in the ancient Near East, especially in a desert environment. Providing water for livestock was a significant task, demanding considerable physical labor and displaying kindness, generosity, and a strong work ethic. Camels, known for their ability to drink large quantities of water after a long journey, posed a particularly challenging demand. Offering to water not only the man but also his camels was a gesture that demonstrated exceeding hospitality and selfless service. The willingness to undertake such a laborious task was viewed as a positive character trait, aligning with the values Abraham sought in a wife for his son. Marriage was viewed as a covenant, not just between two individuals, but between two families. Choosing a wife from Abraham's relatives was vital to preserve their lineage, culture, and faith, preventing assimilation into Canaanite society. Eliezer's prayer requesting a sign from God and his subsequent interpretation of Rebekah's actions reveals a belief in divine guidance and a desire to align his actions with God's will. This entire process underscores the cultural importance of arranged marriages, the emphasis on familial purity, and the value placed on virtues such as hospitality and diligence in a potential spouse.
meaning: Eliezer's prayer and interpretation of Rebekah's actions showcase several theological themes. First, it highlights the sovereignty of God in directing human affairs. Eliezer believes that God has a specific woman chosen for Isaac, and he seeks divine confirmation of this choice. This underscores the concept of God's providence, where He orchestrates events to fulfill His purposes. Second, the verse emphasizes the importance of prayer and seeking God's will in major life decisions. Eliezer doesn't rely solely on his judgment but humbly asks for God's guidance. This serves as a model for believers to prioritize prayer when making significant choices. Third, Rebekah's selfless act of offering water to Eliezer and his camels is symbolic of Christ-like service. Her willingness to go above and beyond demonstrates love, compassion, and a servant's heart. This reflects the Christian call to love others sacrificially and to meet their needs. Fourth, the story foreshadows the concept of God's chosen people and the importance of maintaining spiritual purity. Abraham's insistence on finding a wife for Isaac from his own people reflects God's desire for His followers to remain distinct from the ungodly influences of the world. This also points towards the messianic line through which Jesus would be born. Finally, the verse underscores the theme of divine appointment. Eliezer recognizes that the woman who exhibits the specified qualities will be the one whom the Lord has appointed. This highlights the belief that God has a plan for each person's life and that He guides those who seek Him with a sincere heart.
application: Genesis 24:44 provides several relevant principles for modern life. Firstly, it encourages intentional prayer when making significant life decisions, particularly regarding marriage and relationships. Just as Eliezer sought God's guidance, we should diligently pray for wisdom and discernment in choosing a life partner. This extends beyond romantic relationships to include career choices, major investments, and other important decisions. Secondly, the verse emphasizes the value of selfless service and hospitality. Rebekah's willingness to go the extra mile to serve Eliezer and his camels demonstrates a spirit of generosity and compassion that should characterize Christian living. We can apply this by looking for opportunities to serve others, even when it requires sacrifice or inconvenience. This could involve volunteering time, offering practical help, or simply showing kindness to those in need. Thirdly, it reminds us to look for character qualities that align with biblical values. While physical attraction and compatibility are important, the story highlights the significance of inner virtues such as diligence, kindness, and a servant's heart. We should seek partners who embody these qualities, reflecting God's character. Fourthly, we should trust in God's providential hand in our lives. While we must actively make wise choices, we should also recognize that God is working behind the scenes to guide us and fulfill His purposes. This requires surrendering control and trusting that God will lead us according to His perfect plan. Fifthly, the story prompts us to consider the spiritual implications of our choices. Just as Abraham sought to preserve his lineage's faith, we should prioritize our spiritual well-being and seek relationships that encourage spiritual growth. Surrounding ourselves with godly influences helps us stay on the path of righteousness.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for your unwavering guidance and provision in our lives. We acknowledge that you have a plan for each of us, and we humbly seek your direction in all our decisions. Grant us the wisdom to discern your will, especially in matters of the heart. Help us to cultivate a spirit of selfless service and hospitality, reflecting your love to those around us. May we be mindful of the character qualities that align with your values, seeking partners who embody kindness, diligence, and a servant's heart. Strengthen our trust in your providential hand, knowing that you are working for our good, even when we cannot see it. Help us to prioritize our spiritual well-being and to surround ourselves with influences that encourage our growth in faith. We surrender our lives to you, trusting that you will lead us according to your perfect plan. In Jesus' name, amen.

faqs.answer: Watering camels was a significant test because it demonstrated a servant's heart and immense physical stamina. Camels can drink a lot of water after traveling, requiring significant effort to draw and provide it. It showcased generosity beyond mere courtesy.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Why was watering the camels such a significant test?

faqs.answer: The story reflects the cultural context of arranged marriages, highlighting the importance of familial approval and the desire to preserve cultural and religious values within the family line. While arranged marriages are less common today, the emphasis on family involvement in significant decisions remains relevant.
